column1: he traditional contractor shop and small enterprise will have a smaller and even less secure role unless linked to sophisticated intermediary agents in the channel. [SEP] In short, the paths these industries follow will be determined by their interconnection with one another. [SEP] Providing a stitch—or a package of pasta, a home computer, an automobile—in time requires a growing degree of integration among business enterprises within and across industries. [SEP] Whether it is Federated Department Stores’ or Home Depot’s use of point-of-sales information for inventory control; Levi Strauss’s or Black and Decker’s efforts at customizing products to suit very specific consumer groups; or VF’s or Dell Computer’s innovations to provide product diversity more efficiently, channel integration is
column3: the current industrial transformation—and will continue to do so in the period ahead.

column1: tion, order fulfillment, and transportation. [SEP] And it is in some of these areas, particularly distribution and order fulfillment, that channel dynamics have undergone substantial change during the last decade. [SEP] Supply channels are not new, of course; for centuries, fabric-makers have sold their wares to those who cut and sew garments. [SEP] But, until recently, most channels in the textile and apparel industries have been characterized by arm’s-length relationships among relatively autonomous firms. [SEP] It is only since the mid-1980s that a number of market and technological changes have encouraged companies to enhance the links among different stages of production and distribution. [SEP] Indeed, retailers like Wal-Mart Stores, Kmart Corporation, and Dillard’s Inc. have been the
column3: forces behind changes in manufacturing and logistics systems in a way that was unheard of in Bond Stores’ time. [SEP] For instance, entrepreneur Sam Walton built a retail juggernaut that began with thirty-nine Wal-Mart stores in 1971 and grew to almost three thousand by 1996. [SEP] He did so by insisting that suppliers implement information technologies for exchanging sales data, adopt standards for product labeling, and use modern methods of material handling that assured customers a variety of products at low prices. [SEP] We contend that this revolution in retailing practices will determine future competitive outcomes in retail-apparel-textile channels. [SEP] These new practices—which we call lean retailing—have compelled apparel producers to reorganize the manner in which they relate to

column1: e of apparel sold. [SEP] The majority of fashion products also have a short selling life—usually one season—but are produced for a broader market. [SEP] At the triangle’s bottom are basic products that remain in a retailer’s or manufacturer’s collection for several years, such as men’s white dress shirts or underwear. [SEP] Basics -historically constituted the majority of apparel products sold. [SEP] In the middle of the triangle are fashion-basic products, typically variants on a basic item but containing some fashion element (such as stonewashed jeans or khaki pants with pleats or trim). [SEP] This expanding center of the fashion triangle indicates where the industry is headed. [SEP] Because a growing percentage of basic apparel items have some fashion content, fashion-basic products are
column3: product proliferation. [SEP] Product proliferation and shorter product cycles, reflected in ever-changing styles and product differentiation, contribute to general demand uncertainty for both retailers and manufacturers, thereby making demand forecasting and production planning harder every day. [SEP] In a world where manufacturers must supply an increasing number of products with fashion elements, speed and flexibility are crucial capabilities for firms wrestling with product proliferation, whether they are retailers trying to offer a wide range of choices to consumers or manufacturers responding to retail demands for shipments.

column1: ings have taken advantage of these new outlets—for example, producing Disney-character sheets for retail—but a new dynamic is also developing with apparel-makers, who want shorter runs of materials much more quickly from their textile suppliers. [SEP] Historically, the textile-apparel relationship involved long lead times or advance commitments to secure the necessary cloth in the right style, texture, and patterns. [SEP] This occurred not only because of the greater concentration of businesses in the textile industry, but because textile companies generally plan to run their expensive capital equipment at full capacity around the clock. [SEP] Our research indicates that the relationships between firms in the textile and apparel industries remain underdeveloped, with new competitive forces

[SEP] As Alfred Chandler and other business historians have made clear, successive changes in information exchange and transport over the last century have reshaped relations among industries, as well as the internal organization of these enterprises. column1: with rules Vygotsky regarded the sociodramatic play of the preschool years as essential for further development of play—speciﬁcally, for movement toward game play in middle childhood. [SEP] In make-believe, the rules of play are implicit; preschoolers are hardly aware of enacting them. [SEP] Instead, they are caught up in creating imaginary situations—putting a stuffed animal to bed,
column3: an ambulance to a train crash, or ringing up a customer’s purchase at the cash register. [SEP] Winning and losing, team membership and competition, and purposefully laying down rules are not of great interest to preschoolers. [SEP] Try playing a rule-based game with a 3- or 4-year-old, and you are likely to ﬁnd that the child is easily sidetracked. [SEP] If, with your prompting and guidance, the child does ﬁnish the game, he or she might say, “I won!” or “Everybody won!” regardless of the outcome. [SEP] With age, the imaginativeness of play recedes. [SEP] In the games that captivate school-age children, rules come to the forefront.17 [SEP] Six- to 8-year-olds are often preoccupied with working out the rules of a game and making sure all players follow them. column1: Low Rider The expression “low rider” is used to describe the car, the subculture, and the person who drives a vehicle that has been lowered, rides very low, and has been customized. [SEP] A car, truck, bicycle, van, or motorcycle that has been lowered—and this can be achieved by various methods—means that it sits very close to the ground and has a sleek streamlined appearance. [SEP] The driver and/or owner is called a low rider and the act of low riding refers to all the activities associated with
column3: the car: cruising, caravanning, and hopping. [SEP] Low riders have commonly been associated with cholos (1990s urban youth) and gangs, but traditionally Chicanos seriously involved in low riding and customizing low-rider cars are not involved in gangs, and low-rider clubs actually present an alternative to gang involvement. [SEP] Low-rider car clubs communicate a message of cultural pride and unity. [SEP] Although different, the cholo subculture can be closely linked to the low-rider subculture. [SEP] It is not clear when low riding started, but it was already a custom by the 1930s in Los Angeles and Sacramento, although the name “low rider” did not come into usage until the 1960s. [SEP] After World War II, because of the growth in the economy, many Chicanos could afford to buy cars, old an

column1: Low riders are usually young urban Chicanos, between the ages of eighteen and thirty, and there can be two and three generations of low riders in one family. [SEP] The cost of fixing and maintaining a low-rider car is fairly high, so the owner typically is a working person. [SEP] Since finding older cars, say from the 1950s, is becoming difficult, some low riders now customize small trucks, motorcycles, and bicycles as well. column1: ation consisting of North and South, white and black, native and immigrant, and there were undoubtedly many people displeased by the idea. [SEP] Yet, this was the situation in which we found ourselves in 1863. [SEP] Lincoln had conceived of rooting our history in the identity generated by the struggle for independence. [SEP] History had forged a unique nation of people of diverse origins. [SEP] Justice Harlan understood what the nation had become and what it could do to further its own internal harmony. [SEP] His magisterial dissent leaves us with a historical record of what constitutional thought in the postbellum period could have been. [SEP] Instead of integrating our nationhood and the commitment to equality into constitutional discourse, the Civil Rights Cases completed the process of
column3: Lincoln’s vision into the deep structure of our constitutional thought. [SEP] The Court generated a surface discourse to camouflage the Secret Constitution. [SEP] It bequeathed to us a narrow conception of state action that we are still struggling to overcome. [SEP] And, more to the point, by undermining federal authority to remove the incidents and marks of slavery, the Court facilitated segregation in American society. [SEP] It would be a mere dozen or so years until the Supreme Court upheld the idea that public facilities, including schools, might be “separate but equal”—thus institutionalizing apartheid for generations.53 [SEP] At the same time that the courts drove the postbellum legal order underground, concerted action by the children of slave owners organized to frustrate the purpos

column1: ernal world during the power stroke, then the outside world doing work on the cylinder piston system when you pushed on the piston to recompress the working gas. [SEP] The Carnot cycle links mechanical and thermal energy sources into a work cycle. [SEP] A chemical reaction network with a work cycle will have to link spontaneous, exergonic and nonspontaneous, endergonic reactions into the chemical analogue of a work cycle. [SEP] Like the cyclic Carnot engine, the chemical analogue will have to work in a cycle of states, like the 1, 2, 3, 4, 1 cycle of the Carnot cycle. [SEP] Further, in order for the cycle to operate at a finite rate, hence irreversibly, the autonomous agent must be an open thermodynamic system driven by outside sources of matter or energy = hence “food” = and the continual
column3: of the system by such “food” holds the system away from equilibrium. [SEP] In this light, think again of the Ghadiri autocatalytic system, the 32-amino-acid sequence A that ligates two fragments A’, a 15-amino-acid fragment, and A”, a 17-amino-acid fragment, into A. This reaction is purely exergonic. [SEP] The reaction proceeds from the substrate fragments A’ and A’’ to form the product molecule A and approaches the equilibrium ratio of substrates to product. [SEP] Ghadiri’s autocatalytic system is wonderful, but merely exergonic. [SEP] It does not achieve a work cycle. [SEP] In general, autocatalytic and collectively autocatalytic systems can be purely exergonic. [SEP] In any such case, no work cycle is achieved.

column1: and I are the only members of a tiny economy. [SEP] You begin life with an endowment of a thousand pears and a hundred apples. [SEP] I begin life with an endowment of a hundred pears and a thousand apples. [SEP] Suppose your happiness, or “utility,” would increase if you had fewer rather than more pears and more rather than fewer apples. [SEP] Alas, you have more pears than apples. [SEP] I, in turn, happen to have desires such that I would be happier with rather more pears than apples. [SEP] Alas, I have more apples than pears. [SEP] You and I have advantages of trade. [SEP] We can both be happier if we swap some of my apples for some of your pears. [SEP] It is essential to understand that, indeed, both of us can be better oV by trading. [SEP] Advantages of trade are the fundamental factor
column3: trade itself in an economy. [SEP] In an actual simple economic model, advantages of trade are studied in an “Edgeworth box.” [SEP] Edgeworth invented a two-dimensional box representation of values, or “worths,” plotted along the edge of his box (Figure 3.6). [SEP] In the Edgeworth box, I am represented at the bottom-left corner, you are represented at the top-right corner. [SEP] A family of equal happiness, or “isoutility” curves, show your “isohappiness” trade-oVs of apples and pears at any total abundance to you of apples and pears. [SEP] You are, in general, happier the more total apples and pears you have. [SEP] Your happiness landscape increases from low to high like a cone-shaped mountain whose peak is located over my head. [SEP] On that peak, you have all the apples and pears in the

column1: the random motions of the gas particles, but there is no means to extract mechanical work from it, say, to drive a piston. [SEP] Next, says Maxwell, warming to his point, “Imagine that my wee friend operates the flap valve such that, whenever a fast gas particle approaches the window from inside the left box toward the right box, he opens the flap and lets the faster than average, hence hotter, gas particle through. And suppose my demon also operates the flap value to let the slower than average, hence cooler, gas particles pass from the right to the left box. Well, soon the left box will be cool and the right box will be hot. And now,” concludes Maxwell with a broad smile, “we can use the macroscopic temperature dierence between the left and right boxes to extract mechanical work, say, by
column3: a piston.” [SEP] There you have it. [SEP] Maxwell posed a severe question for statistical mechanics and the second law. [SEP] It appeared that the actions of the demon might circumvent the second law.

column1: pts of matter, energy, entropy, and information, we lack a coherent concept of organization, its emergence, and self-constructing propagation and self-elaboration. [SEP] If we do not yet understand organization fully, we can at least think about what happens in autonomous agents such as real cells. [SEP] A real cell, a real molecular autonomous agent, does in fact carry out self-reproduction. [SEP] In addition, it carries out one or more real work cycles, linking spontaneous and nonspontaneous processes. [SEP] It does, in fact, measure, detect, and record sources of energy and does do work to construct constraints on the release of energy, which when released in the constrained way, propagates to do more work, often constructing further constraints on the release of energy or doing work by
column3: further nonspontaneous processes. [SEP] Cells do achieve propagating work. [SEP] The work propagating in a cell achieves a “closure” in a set of propagating work tasks such that the cell literally constructs a rough copy of itself. [SEP] In a later chapter I will return to discussing “tasks,” which turn out on a Darwinian analysis to be a subset of the causal consequences of the release of energy at a point and time in the system. [SEP] For the moment, I want to focus on the concept of a closure in a set of propagating “work tasks.”

column1: Unlike “know that,” “know-how” does not involve propositions about the world. [SEP] “Know-how” involves procedural knowledge about how to get on in the world. [SEP] The cheetah streaking after the wildebeest, the athletic genius high jumping, have the know-how to do it. [SEP] Does a bacterium know how to make a living in its world? [SEP] I certainly want to say yes, without attributing consciousness in any way. [SEP] Watch the myriad subtle turnings on and o of genes, metabolic switching, mechanical twitching, sensing of glucose gradient, swimming and tumbling upstream to higher glucose concentrations. [SEP] It knows how all right, even if it cannot talk about how it gets on with its business. [SEP] But then, try to talk about tying your shoes or the skilled
column3: when you become aware some dozens of miles down the road that you have accomplished the tasks without paying the slightest focused attention. [SEP] Thank God for know-how. [SEP] Know that is a thin veneer on a four-billion-year-old know-how skill abundant in the biosphere. [SEP] But any autonomous agent proliferating alone or in a congery of other agents, it would seem, is also graced by the selfsame know-how. [SEP] If we synthesize autonomous agents in the next decades and they coevolve under our rapt gaze over months or years into a modestly complex ecosystem brimming with novel life forms, they too will know how to make a living in their mutually created world plus the boundary conditions we more or less intelligently impose on them.

column1: of the actual exist. [SEP] Those in the adjacent possible do not exist  at least within the volume of the universe we are talking about, which we can expand in a moment to be the actual molecular diversity of the entire universe, not just our tiny patch of it. [SEP] The chemical potential of a single reaction with a single set of substrates and no products is perfectly definable, both the enthalpy and entropy. [SEP] But we hardly need that sophistication. [SEP] The substrates are present in the actual, and the products are not present in the actual, but only in the adjacent possible. [SEP] It follows that every such reaction couple is displaced from its equilibrium in the direction of an excess of substrates compared to its products. [SEP] This displacement constitutes a chemical potential
column3: the reaction toward equilibrium. [SEP] The simple conclusion is that there is a real chemical potential from the actual to the adjacent possible. [SEP] Other things being equal, the total system “wants” to flow into the adjacent possible. [SEP] If there are to trillion organic molecules in the biosphere and each pair of organic molecules can undergo at least one two substrate–two product reaction, then the diversity of reactions is the square of the diversity of molecular species, hence about x = . [SEP] Some substantial fraction of these reactions flow from the actual to the adjacent possible. [SEP] The total chemical potential from the actual into the adjacent possible is hard to estimate, but it is certainly not small.

column1: ther, perhaps generic, property that appears to drive such systems to settle down, then change in a sudden burst. [SEP] As the system of agents and actions settles down to some repeatable behavior, an increasingly wide range of alternative theories, simple and very complex, fit the same data. [SEP] But the complex theories, with many Fourier modes, attempt to predict fine details of the repeatable behavior. [SEP] As those theories become more complex, they are more fragile because they can be disconfirmed by ever more minor fluctuations in the repeatable behavior. [SEP] Sooner or later such a fluctuation happens, and the agents with the complex disconfirmed theories change theories and actions radically, setting up a vast avalanche of changes of theories and actions that sweeps the system,
column3: the collective behavior far from any repeatable pattern. [SEP] In these new circumstances, only a small subset of theories fits the current facts, so the diversity, and complexity, of theories in the population of agents plummets, and the system finds its way back to some repeatable pattern of behavior. [SEP] In short, there appears to be not only a bounded complexity in our rationality, but a fragility - stability cyclic oscillation in our joint theories and actions as well. [SEP] In these terms, the system of agents and theories never settles down to a fixed-point equilibrium in which markets clear. [SEP] Instead, the system repeatedly fluctuates away from the contract curve then returns to new points in the vicinity of the contract curve. [SEP] Hence, in precisely the sense of repeatedly

column1: World, the more objects there are in the economy, the more complement and substitute relations exist among those objects, as well as potential new objects in the adjacent possible. [SEP] If there are N objects, the number of potential complement or substitute relations scales at least as N squared since each object might be a complement or substitute of any object. [SEP] Thus, as the diversity of the objects in the web increases, the diversity of prospective niches for new goods and services increases even more rapidly! [SEP] The very diversity of the economic web is autocatalytic. [SEP] If this view is correct, then diversity of goods and services is a major driver of economic growth. [SEP] Indeed, I believe that the role of diversity of goods and services is the major unrecognized factor
column3: economic growth. [SEP] Jane Jacobs had made the same point in her thoughtful books about the relation between economic growth and economic diversity of cities and their hinterlands. [SEP] Economist Jose Scheinkman, now chairman of economics at the University of Chicago, and his colleagues studied a number of cities, normalized for total capitalization, and found that economic growth correlated with economic diversity in the city. [SEP] In a similar spirit, microfinancing of a linked diversity of cottage businesses in the third world and the first world seems to be achieving local economic growth where more massive eorts at education and infrastructure, Aswan dams and power grids, seem to fail. [SEP] Indeed, in the same way in an ecosystem, organisms create niches for other organisms. [SEP]

column1: y villages of all stripes have sprung up, so wherever you are based, you’ll never be far from a good beach, a reasonably sized town, village, or resort, shops, and nightlife. [SEP] The following pages cover the Algarve traveling west to east, though you could certainly do the reverse or begin in the center, near Faro (or anywhere you elect to stay) and embark on day trips both east and west from there. [SEP] For those with additional time and interest in seeing more of Portugal, a brief section on the Portuguese capital Lisbon and its seductive environs is included. [SEP] Lisbon is about four hours by car (and 40 minutes by plane) from Faro; it should be conceived as an add-on to your visit to the Algarve rather than a day trip. [SEP] Many people visit the Algarve by flying into Lisbon and
column3: to the southern coast. [SEP] If you are flying directly to the international airport at Faro and wish to spend a few days in the Lisbon area, it would make sense to see about a return flight from there. [SEP] World’s End: Sagres and Cabo de São Vicente

column1: opment of diving to the modern SCUBA (self-contained underwater breathing apparatus) method developed by Jacques Cousteau in the 1930s. [SEP] There is also a good restaurant on site, the Brass Helmet. [SEP] A short boatride from Port Lucaya takes you to Sanctuary Bay and the UNEXSO Dolphin Experience. [SEP] A family of bottlenose dolphins have set up home here. [SEP] You can linger by the side of the bay and hope they come to you, get in the water and swim with them, or spend a day as an assistant trainer and help the staff care for these gentle creatures. [SEP] Just north of the Marina is the Lucayan Golf and Country Club, which has some of the best-groomed greens in the Bahamas and a very good restaurant for those who want to watch rather than play — diners enjoy panoramic views over the
column3: range and several holes. [SEP] Freeport-Lucaya may be a modern town of concrete and tarmac, but within the city limits are two natural areas that could be a million miles away from the bustle of the shops and large hotels. [SEP] Rand Memorial Nature Centre, on 100 acres of land on East Settlers Way to the east of Freeport, is used as a resource for students on the island, but there’s nothing dry and academic about it. [SEP] Here you can learn about the plants native to the Bahamas and find out which ones were used for bush medicine and for what purpose. [SEP] A flock of flamingos and numerous other native bird species make their home here.

column1: els sprawl amid spacious grounds next to dazzling white beaches, with two championship golf courses, a convention center at the Sheraton Nusa Indah Hotel, and the Galleria, a modern shopping and restaurant complex in the same area. [SEP] Predictably, lower-priced hotels and affordable eating places line the 5 km (3 miles) of coast north of Nusa Dua’s hotel zone, all the way to Benoa. [SEP] Once a dusty, somnolent fishing village, Benoa has turned into a watersports center of buzzing jet skis, motorboats, diving centers, and bars. [SEP] Don’t confuse Benoa village (Tanjung Benoa) with Benoa Port, on the opposite (north) side of the muddy inlet known as Benoa Harbor. [SEP] Reached from the Sanur-Kuta road by a long causeway, the harbor is where cargo ships tie up. [SEP] There is a charge for
column3: along the causeway to the jetty, and no reason for going to the end unless you plan to take the fast twin-hull, Maubua Express ferry to Lombok, a cruise to Nusa Lembongan, or a deep-sea fishing trip. [SEP] Jimbaran Beach is a great arc of sand facing a sheltered bay south of the airport, shared by a handful of resort hotels and a fishing village. [SEP] More hotels are rapidly going up on a new access road that runs parallel to the coast here. [SEP] Look for the sign to Uluwatu on the road from the airport toward Nusa Dua — you have to pass it and then make a U-turn. [SEP] Jimbaran Beach is famous for its restaurants that serve fresh grilled fish and seafood on the beach.

column1: at the Shidu Bungee Jumping Facility in the Fangshan District), paintball (at Color Me Purple in Wanfangting Park), rock climbing (at the Qidagudu Climbing Club in the Xuanwu District), horseback riding (check with the Movenpick Hotel), and shooting (at the China North Shooting Range near the Great Wall Badaling — where even machine guns are for rent). [SEP] Golf. [SEP] Beijing’s top course is the Beijing International Golf Club, located near the Ming Tombs. [SEP] The Beijing Grand Canal Golf Club, east of Beijing, has night golf. [SEP] Near the airport, the Beijing Country Golf Club provides 36 holes. [SEP] The newest championship golf course, designed by Graham Marsh, is the Huatang International Golf. [SEP] The closest course to the city is the Chaoyang Golf Club, a 9-hole course with a
column3: range. [SEP] All these courses are open to the public (make reservations through your hotel), and they rent clubs and provide caddies. [SEP] Greens fees start at about 1,000 yuan. [SEP] Bowling. [SEP] Modern bowling lanes enjoyed a boom in Beijing during the 1990s, with alleys located in the Holiday Inn Lido, Beijing International, and other hotels. [SEP] The bowling alley in the lower basement of the China World Hotel has special off-hour rates during the day.

column1: World War II In the autumn of 1938, Hitler was put out that Berliners did not share his enthusiasm for the cavalcade of troops
column3: through the city. [SEP] The army was preparing its march into what used to be Czechoslovakia, but onlookers shared none of the fervor that had greeted military parades in 1914. [SEP] Their disquiet was shortly to be justified by the hail of bombs on the capital. [SEP] The first attacks came in 1940 from the British in retaliation for the air raids on London. [SEP] Attacks were stepped up after the German defeat at Stalingrad in 1943, with Anglo-American “carpet-bombing.” [SEP] The worst single raid was on 6 February 1945, when bombs wiped out 4 sq km (1 1⁄2 sq miles) of the city center in one hour.

column1: Billiards and bowling. [SEP] “Billiards,” which also includes ten-pin bowling, snooker, and pool, is a very popular pastime in Budapest. [SEP] For a list of venues ask Tourinform or see the Sports and Leisure section in the Budapest Sun. [SEP] Golf. [SEP] This is a newcomer to Hungary, and you will have to drive some way out of town if you want to play. [SEP] The Budapest Golf Course is a 9-hole, par 36 course with
column3: range, 35 km (22 miles) north at Kisoroszi (tel. 1170-6025). [SEP] Bookings are required. [SEP] The nearest 18-hole course is 200 km (120 miles) away to the west in Bükk. [SEP] Horseback riding. [SEP] There are numerous good stables and horse-riding schools just outside Budapest, and riding holidays around the Balaton area and farther aﬁeld are on offer at Budapesti Equestrian Club (tel. 313-5210) and Petoreházy Club Hotel (tel. 176-5937). [SEP] Ask Tourinform for details, pay a visit to the aptly-named Pegazus Tours on Fereciek tere, or see the IBUSZ brochure, Riding in Hungary.

column1: Marin County Immediately north of San Francisco are two charming waterfront towns — Sausalito and Tiburon — which you can reach either by
column3: across the Golden Gate Bridge or by taking a ferry — from the Ferry Building at the foot of Market Street, or Pier 41 near Fisherman’s Wharf. [SEP] Tiburon is the quieter of the two, while Sausalito is more of a tourist trap, but both have a colorful Mediterranean atmosphere, with art galleries, yacht harbors, craft shops, and pleasant bistros and cafés out on the boardwalk overlooking the bay.

column1: Accommodatingly situated on the border between Ontario and Québec, Ottawa is a fully bilingual city, though most of the French-speaking community (and the best restaurants) now have their homes in Hull on the Québec side of the Ottawa River. [SEP] Except for longer excursions, try to leave the car in the hotel parking lot and walk or take the bus. [SEP] The complex system of one-way streets designed to avoid rather than to reach key government buildings, and the added confusion of curving rivers and canals, make downtown
column3: a harrowing business even for locals. [SEP] One other point: In the absence of any clear logic in street numbering, it’s important when noting an address to be sure you have the nearest cross-streets as well as the number of the building. [SEP] Parliament Area

column1: Highway 4 follows the lake shore to Cathedral Grove, a formidable stand of Douglas firs in MacMillan Provincial Park, donated to the public by a paper manufacturer as a gesture for government permission to exploit less accessible parts of the forest. [SEP] Many of the firs, up to 76 m (230 ft) high, are more than 300 years old, the most ancient dating back to the 12th century. [SEP] Excellent explanatory panels trace the growth of these majestic trees. [SEP] Off the beaten track, you’ll steep yourself in the atmosphere of a truly primeval forest. [SEP] Stock up on picnic supplies in the town of Port Alberni before
column3: on past Kennedy Lake and down to Pacific Rim National Park. [SEP] Its sandy beaches are a delight, the powerful ocean-breakers being particularly admired by champion surfers. [SEP] At the coast, Highway 4 turns north along one of the best resort areas, the self-explanatory Long Beach, 12 km (7 miles) of fine sand and first-class fishing waters. [SEP] Hotels here provide you with cooking facilities for whatever fish you — or a generous neighbor — might catch. [SEP] The boardwalk that rambles along Wickaninnish Bay will take you in and out of the coastal pine forest. [SEP] Florencia Bay is a good bathing beach, while South Bay is the mecca for collectors of “worry stones.” [SEP] These exquisite green, aubergine, or (most prized of all) jet black pebbles are gathered from hidden nooks and cran

column1: r, there is the unusually dense growth of trees and fauna in what is the Parque Nacional Garajonay (open Tuesday–Sunday 9:30am–4:30pm). [SEP] Less than 20 km (121⁄2 miles) from north to south, this amazing island has been declared a Property of Humanity by UNESCO. [SEP] In fact, a third of the island, 12,450 hectares (30,774 acres) has been designated into seventeen protected areas. [SEP] Such terrain, though, makes for difficulty in getting around, and even the Romans, had they ventured this way, would have found their legendary ability to build straight roads put to an impossible test. [SEP] In fact, almost nowhere on the island will you find a straight stretch of road, everywhere you go the roads twist and turn continually, often turning back on themselves in hairpin bends. [SEP] Making
column3: even more complicated is the fact that the roads, although improving, are often of poor quality, and the directional signs leave much to be desired. [SEP] Just 40 minutes away from Tenerife, La Gomera nevertheless remains unspoiled and authentic, with its steep, green, terraced hills and tranquil valleys.

column1: Ronda The opening of an improved road from San Pedro de Alcántara to Ronda has ended the isolation of this mountain area, and shortened the
column3: time from the coast to an hour. [SEP] One of the most spectacularly situated towns in Europe, Ronda sits atop a cliff-bound plateau, cleaved through the middle by a sheer-sided gorge. [SEP] The older, Moorish part of town (La Ciudad) lies to the south of the ravine, linked by an 18th-century bridge to El Mercadillo, the modern district that arose after the Reconquista. [SEP] The gorge, known as El Tajo, is a deep and narrow crevasse that plunges 150 m (490 ft) to the foaming Río Guadalevín, a tributary of the Guadiaro River. [SEP] During the Civil War, nationalist sympathizers in the town were hurled to their deaths in the gorge, an event recalled by Hemingway in his novel For Whom the Bell Tolls. [SEP] You can enjoy a superb view of the Tajo and the patchwork of fields beyond from the Puen

column1: There are beaches and excellent diving farther west, near Playa María la Gorda, but for most visitors the star attractions are the irresistible town of Viñales and its beautiful valley. [SEP] Many visitors take organized daytrips of the region from Havana hotels, but an overnight stay in Viñales — overlooking the valley — is highly recommended. [SEP] Start your explorations by
column3: west on the autopista (highway) linking Havana with the province’s capital city of Pinar del Río. [SEP] About 63 km (39 miles) along the highway, a turnoff leaves the level, palm-dotted plains for Soroa, where a richly endowed botanical garden nestles in the mountain foothills near a tired little tourist complex. [SEP] A guided tour reveals an orchid garden, lychee and mango trees, coffee plants, and splendid specimens of jagüey and ceiba trees. [SEP] A restaurant in the villa of Castillo de las Nubes on a nearby mountain has stunning views. [SEP] At the end of the highway, 175 km (109 miles) west of Havana, the small city of Pinar del Río is a bustling commercial center. [SEP] Along the main street, Calle José Martí, low-rise neoclassical buildings in blues, yellows, greens, and orange hav

column1: Upriver from the sandbank at its mouth, the Douro runs between Porto and the port lodges of Vila Nova de Gaia, passing beneath a series of impressive bridges and on towards port-wine territory. [SEP] The railway line from Porto skips the first 60 km (37 miles) of the river — but this is the least interesting stretch. [SEP] The line eventually joins the river near Ribadouro, proceeding along the northern bank, past small towns and fields where the haystacks, set on cross-shaped supports, look from a distance like scarecrows. [SEP] Attractive Amarante sits on a gorge of the Tâmega (a tributary of the Douro) and makes a good stop if you are
column3: along the road from Porto towards Mesã Frio and Régua. [SEP] Baronial mansions with gaily painted balconies overlooking the river line the streets. [SEP] Rising above a handsome stone arched bridge and leafy park, the church of the former 16th-century monastery of São Gonçalo is well worth a visit, especially if you are looking for love: It hosts a pilgrimage in June for women seeking husbands (with the exchange of phallic-shaped cakes—a remarkably literal step in the mating dance). [SEP] The river bends and twists, widens and narrows among green terraced hills. [SEP] The port trade prompted the growth of Peso da Régua (usually called just Régua), 70 km (43 miles) east of Porto. [SEP] Régua was once the main port used to ship young wines downriver in barcos rabelos (flat-bottomed wooden boa
